It's probably an age thing. If you saw the original version then there's no contest between Alec Guinness and Ian Richardson and Gary Oldman and Colin Firth. The latter do their best, but it doesn't get within a mile of the original. No menace and very little drama in comparison.For those who've penned effusive praise of this version, give yourselves an early Christmas present and see the original.I was particularly disappointed by the meeting in the safe house. It was confusing at best and unfathomable at worst. Oscar standard - I think not.

Review title: If you liked the trailer then save your money and wait for the pop-up
Review_body: There has only been one other film that wasted my money more than this one and that was "Birth." From the trailer I was expecting a heart stopping action packed thriller. It was neither. The story was very disjointed. The director tried to tie it all together at the end but I was already tired of it by then. The acting was so-so, typically British. It was dark and I felt like I had just been exposed to a series of unrelated clips. Anyone who likes this movie must like drinking fish oil. Like I said, save your money. I have to say that in the film Birth at least it could have been revived by a simple rewrite of the ending. I could not imagine any kind of rewrite that could have even brought this film up to zombie category let alone alive. Half way through the movie you finally get a sense of what the heck Tinker, Tailor and Sailor had to do with the film but I must have dosed off when the Spy aspect became apparent. I was waiting and waiting but it never came. I would have included a spoiler in this review just to help dissuade readers from wasting their money but I don't think I could come up with climactic ending. I see a lot of movies and have never written a review because I never felt strong enough one way or the other until this one.

If anybody says they could follow this movie without having read the book, they are not telling the truth. The movie is unnecessarily complex and confusing and not the least bit enjoyable to watch.I would advise people to skip the first 2 hours of this movie and just catch the final 8 minutes. They will find out everything they need to know without having to endure a great deal of confusion and frustration.I think this movie falls into the same category as the story about The Emperor Who Had No Clothes. People just aren't willing to admit that that they didn't know what the heck was going on.

I'm a huge fan of spy movies! I loved The Day of the Jackal, The Bourne Identity. However, this film fails on so many levels it's hard to know where to start. First, we learn almost nothing about the characters. Secondly, I really got tired of watching filing, shuffling of papers, and scenes of men sitting in chairs over and over without any real action. The cuts back and forth are confusing, the actors look extremely unattractive, and most of the scenes are of men sitting down and talking. Or not talking. They stare, they stare again, they mutter. I found this film to be toxic it was so dull. And if the scenes are from the 1970s, how about sideburns on the men? Or double vented suits? This film was a terrible disappointment.

Being John Le Carre's (and this particular novel's) faithful fan for so many years, - I've been impatiently waiting for this film to appear, and even contemplating pre-order of the BluRay version scheduled to hit the shelves on January the 30th. In my impatience I could've never imagined the 2011 version of "Tinker Tailor Soldier Spy" would appear to be such a disastrous failure... Most surprising has been Mr.John Le Carre's having actually participated in adaptation of the novel for screen : my first impression was the creators of the 2011 version have never read the book properly. I could imagine "squeezing" the novel to 2 hrs of screen-time was not an easy task, but quite a number of changes done to the plot seem completely out of place and utterly unjustified. Garry Oldman is an excellent actor, but who on earth told Mr.Alfredson this actor could actually do George Smiley? Same goes for most of the other characters : except for Control, Bill Haydon, Peter Guillaume and, probably, Connie Sachs and Rikki Tarr (sorry, have omitted little Bill Roach), - they all seem to have nothing to do with Mr.Le Carre's personages. Gone are all the subtleties of the novel, so wonderfully depicted by the BBC TV series of the '70s with great Alec Guinnes (who WAS George Smiley indeed), gone is the whole magic of Mr.Le Carre's epic spy novel. While one could probably applaud the "Circus atmosphere" as created by Mr.Alfredson and his Art- and Photography Directors, - using the Connie Sachs' language (which I don't recall from the book), after leaving the theater one cannot but feel "seriously under-f..ked"...

Review title: Worst movie I've ever seen in a theater, save your money
Review_body: I love history and especially a good story about spies. This movie spends no time on character development so you spend the first hour and a half trying to figure out who the characters are, if they are key players, or don't even matter. This was the first struggle. It was also impossible to figure out or follow the attempt at a plot. The word "mole" was said about a hundred times but this person didn't even seem to matter. What was he even doing and why did anyone care? There was no action whatsoever. How can you have a "spy" movie with Russians, Brits, and Americans but no action? I don't even know how it is impossible to make a bad spy movie. If you liked Breach, Sum of all Fears, Bourne Identity, Clear and Present Danger or similar movies stay home. Don't waste two and a half hours of your life. I actually asked my husband if we could leave halfway through and then just decided to go to sleep.

Review title: One of the worst movies ever - take that other movie you considered instead
Review_body: This movie is a complete waste of time, but let me explain why...It is jumping back and forth in time like a rabbit on too much Redbull without assisting or making it easy for the viewer to follow. There story is not logic at all and you yourself have to fill in the missing pieces if you wish to get some understanding out of the story. The ending is not clear at all and is conducted very quick seeing the time they have wasted on bullshit throughout the movie. The movie is also very slow and doesn't entertain at all, not even your brain as it it's too messy and you spend your time trying to keep up leaving no time to try to puzzle it together.The only positive I have to say is that they really made it look like it was produced in the 70's.I regret that I saw this movie until the end in hope of it puzzling everything together in a brilliant way...which it didn't. I was left completely messed up in my head and really irritated because how worthless this movie was and because of my time wasted on crap. It has been reviewed as extremely good so I expected this to be a decent movie but it didn't even get out of the category worst movies ever.Take my word on it, the good reviews are either due to how the make it appear being produced in the 70's or from brain dead people who builds their personality on being special and therefore constantly jumps on and associate themselves with everything being so odd and irrational or completely not understandable. Bet they say they love this movie out of trying to be special and cultivated but in reality didn't enjoy and get it at all.Your time is better spent on something else!

Review title: This is the worst movie i have ever paid to watch
Review_body: Two hours of old guys looking at each other meaningfully while smoking and trading secrets that have no context. My friend fell asleep and I felt guilty for bringing four people to see such a stinker. When it ended, we all just looked at each other with confused faces. None of us read the book so maybe that was the problem...but seriously, that was the most anti-climatic movie ever. (Two hours of old guys looking at each other meaningfully while smoking and trading secrets that have no context. My friend fell asleep and I felt guilty for bringing four people to see such a stinker. When it ended, we all just looked at each other with confused faces. None of us read the book so maybe that was the problem...but seriously, that was the most anti-climatic movie ever.) ...... I just wrote that twice because I didn't have enough lines the first time to qualify but there is nothing else to say.

This is a horrid waste of time. I put so much effort into deeply understanding the minutia in the film - I dove my hand in its swamp, searching for substance and content, and came up bone dry.My title is a tribute to another user reviewer, chris chris, who got it spot on. The movie feels like it should be something sophisticated, so all it takes is one reviewer to express something vaguely positive to make the other reviewers feel incompetent not to give this movie five starts, because this movie seems like it has to be something awful or terrible.Let me assure you, it is terrible. Don't waste your time and mental energies, is was not worth the electricity used to display it at the theater.

I did not read the book or see the BBC production - was completely confused, as were my husband and the people sitting near us. Plus, bored - I actually fell asleep at one point. No character development, little action - given the book's success I have to assume the fault lies with the film. A dismal adaptation. (updated: apparently you need ten lines of text to post a review: I don't think the film merits that much thought, but let's just say that I agree with other reviewers that the movie is confused, dull, plodding, too much shuffling papers and not enough action, and absolutely a miss for anyone who is not already familiar with the basic story.

Maybe it's because I'm a part-Swedish native English speaker--or maybe Tomas Alfredson's Nordically glacial and dull TTSS-2011 misses the mark on a more straightforward level, but Alfredson's cluelessness of the subtleties and entendres of spoken English weigh especially heavy on this film.TTSS is a decidedly British period piece whodunit with a labyrinthine back story and subtext. In order to enjoy and admire such a work (and be interested in each character), the English dialogue and included idiom and colloquialisms *ARE CENTRAL* to the film as plot points and character raison d'etre. The most important and satisfying elements of the piece lie in its character's use of British vernacular and slang (some Brit spy stuff included), and its dialectical delivery.Le Carre(Novel) and Hopcraft/Irvin (BBC version) got it right, but it's all missing as O'Connor/Straughan, the writers, and the forgivably Swedish Alfredson have "thrown out the baby with the bathwater" in condensing this work to a 127 minute film. None of the characters appear to have much to say at all, with the vacuous staring going on, but when they do speak, we get a foreshortened and 2 dimensional view of their motives and place in the plot; As dull and plodding as a real British spy's life could be in the '70s cold war, we need to be interested and entertained by the peculiarities and persona of each character in a film, and with the exception of the fine performance by Tom Hardy, as Ricki Tarr, most of the cast play as gray and flat as the film comes off in whole.I LOVED the book & '79 BBC version, and lived in London in 1973, so this film should have impressed and satisfied, as much as I would have liked it too upon hearing of the upcoming release in early 2011 - Only it didn't...Other reviewers have praised and extolled the direction, the script, the acting, the musical score, and the photography; And I certainly respect the actors' work in this most subtle and (on the surface) potentially confusing story. But after viewing this film 5 times, I am left loathing a sixth screening.

After feeling unable to continue watching this torturously dull "film" for more than an hour, I feel i can only comment on my experience of the picture rather than the quality of the film on whole. Unless the last hour is a dialogue packed, exhilarating tale of espionage (as it was billed as) this film is at the best, forgettable. Gary Oldman is "brilliant" as a boring and morose character to which he feels he needs to add little personality and memories of Cumberbatch's fantastic portrayal of Sherlock Holmes are the only saving grace for Oldman's co-star. As the film began I felt myself embarrassingly confused but the hope that this hazy introduction would act only as a prelude to an exciting and gripping tale kept me watching. That. Never. Happened. I felt - something I thought was impossible - my eyes closing themselves, and tiredness rapidly set in as I heard one incomprehensible Russian name after another. Maybe this was simply psycho-somatic - my mind telling me this was not for me. However I must give hope to all those that feel similar symptoms, there is a cure - turn the film off. I expected to be gripped by delicately portrayed tales of espionage and secret betrayals, but instead I met only a wooden session of clear script reading (a piece of literature I imagine took up only three pages) and elusions to a mole that i felt no interest in discovering the identity of. Sorry to all those that enjoyed the film, but I felt it draining and miserly. I may try to watch it again in the future, but as for now I will stick to James Bond on the rare occasion I want to watch a spy film.

Review title: Don't count your chickens before they hatch
Review_body: I really did expect more of this type of film. Admittedly it is not quite my usual genre, but after watching the trailer I figured that it may of been more than I expected.Now after watching the film I really do believe that the producers could have done more. A very very slow movie that had me checking the time constantly waiting for some answers. I understand that this is reflective of the era and genre but even so...It seems they pulled all the best parts of the film out for the trailer and left the gruesome and upsetting parts to surprise you with.I was very disappointed by the film. Hopefully this doesn't put me off the whole genre in general.

if you are looking for a film that keeps you on the edge of your seat then this is the film for you...the trouble is when you get to the edge of your seat you will then want to get up and leave the theatre cos this has to be the most dull, dismal, grey, boring film ever made. there is more life in a mortuaryas said in many reviews on this film weeks after leaving the movie theatre I'm still waiting for something to happen.from what i see its worth watching if you have read the book but at least give us some warning before subjecting innocent people to this torture.

The film is EXTREMELY slow, with a single very short action scene. It is difficult to express how underwhelmed me and my party were with this film. Both in pace and in storyline, the film is lacking. Perhaps most disappointing was that both reviewer and viewers ranked it highly. The only possible explanations are either that all of these people read the book,or, that there is some type of strange conspiracy going on here. During the film I left the theater to buy popcorn and was longing for an exciting film. My friend went to see this film and witnessed several people leave during the movie. This is why I cannot believe the ratings and can only imagine a hoax took place. I will not waste another moment on this film. I recommend you do the same.

Tinker, Tailor, Soldier, Spy is the epitome of taking spy movies in the wrong direction. Most positive reviews seem to stem out of thinking condescendingly about people who may not have enjoyed the movie. Having a dialog-intense movie with one or no action scenes does not make a movie even decent. This is just the polar opposite of "Mission Impossible" they are both terrible movies for different reasons. The opening credits of the movie really set the stage for the rest of the movie. It was two guys walking through London followed by an hour and a half of boring, monotonous, robotic dialog. It was one mind- numbing headshot after another. Usually this sort of thing wouldn't bother me if they developed character relationships helped made me care about them as individuals...but they didn't...and I don't. I am giving this movie a two because there was a scene where a fellow was shot to death...that was about as much emotion and excitement the movie contained. I rarely watch a movie constantly checking the time on my phone waiting for it to end. After it ended I left the theater with my girlfriend and she kissed me on the cheek and I remembered I was still a living breathing human being and not a dead clump of cells. We did have a rather nice time complaining about it on the drive home but that isn't enough for a three.

Review title: A beautiful piece, don't look for a Bourne movie here.....
Review_body: I went into this movie never have read the book, or looked at the show, or even read what it was about and loved it. I loved the leisure pace it set and how it unfolds. There was no chase scenes, shootouts-and thank god because I find now a lot of movies are under that genre and it's almost too straightforward at times.At the slower pace, I was able to pick up the subtle clues presented, such as the look on the character's face, or the way they're dress (to indicate if it was a flashback or not. The suspense was wonderful that it wasn't a boiling point like some movies, it unfolded as you were reading a book.I would see it again on DVD because-I loved it, and also to pick up on the clues that I did miss. I felt it needs a sequel to answers some situation that I was curious to know that there wasn't enough movie time to answer.Beautiful cinematography, sets, and the gray tone of the cold war era came through with the well chosen decor of the office and homes to match.

Review title: A marvellously English cold war thriller
Review_body: Tinker Tailor Soldier Spy is without any doubt a wonderfully crafted film set in a recreated 1970s London that exudes a certain eerie realism, from the bare light bulbs to chain smoking it creates the perfect atmosphere for the retelling of John le Carré's classic novel.Tinker tailor soldier spy is in essence a cold war thriller but gone are the explosions and gun shots and heroics, this is a film of internal war. It tells the story of a mole inside the British intelligence service, nicknamed quite aptly 'The Circus', leaking secrets to the Russians and the quest of one old retired spy to find the truth whilst remaining unknown to the upper echelons of the circus. With a quintessentially English feel, from dinner at the wimpy to the disgust that darts across Oldman's face at the slightest sign of unbecoming activity which goes a long way in adding to the Oxbridge old boys characters in the film.One thing that you notice as you watch the film is the fantastic casting for which we have Tom Alfredson and co to thank as it truly elevates the film to a level that could not have been achieved by other actors and strikes a real chord with le Carré's novel. Not simply is this laid at the feet of Gary Oldman (George Smiley) who is in reverence to the book, a man of few words but inspiring presence. Oldman plays Smiley with a majestic manner in which he, much akin to an Oxford old boy and a gentleman, does most of the talking with his unflappable demeanour and patience which for any actor would be a challenge to put forward so much by saying so little but Oldman plays it quite masterfully and reveals Smiley's insecurities with a marvellous intimacy that truly brings Smiley to life from the pages. This film is acted wonderfully throughout, from the ever dapper Collin Firth (Bill Haydon) with his confidence and authority to the gruff military manner of John Hurt (Control) that to any reader of the book will see a near perfect portrayal and anyone who watches the film will see an extraordinary performance.Further note should be given to screen writers Bridget O'Connor and , Peter Straughan who do an excellent service in taking le Carre's mass of characters, plot lines and at times circumlocutory manner and streamlining it into a film of only 2 hours whilst retaining the bulk of the plot and emotion in the book. This is however where to a fan of the book the film falls down as the relationships are all hashed into one scene of a circus party where all the emotional interaction between characters is forced into one room. Which leaves the complex nature of the way Bill is thought of by every character in the book sadly underexposed so too is the character of Jim Prideaux who loses a lot of his depth as a character.Overall however, this is a wonderful film with very little to say against it other than no lover of a book is ever completely happy with its translation to film but in this case it is a damn near perfect job and well worth a watch.

I desperately wanted to be moved by this film. This is one of the most important pieces of literature in the genre and deserved to be introduced to a newer and younger audience. I was expecting something with shark-like bite, but sat through pickled herring instead. Sadly, it was a colossal failure and in no way measures up to the depth and nuance of the book.Several key "actors" were completely missing from the film; namely WW2, Cold War, Vietnam. The backdrop of the film was completely missing. Without somehow acquainting the audience with the wartime experiences of the characters, they appeared to be drawn from the cast of Glengarry Glenross. These were supposed to have been men and women who had a close acquaintance with death, both through the war and on into the Cold War. Where was the gripping tension of the East West nuclear scrum? Why wasn't the spectre of Vietnam even alluded to? Unfortunately, Gary Oldham is completely miscast here. Smiley is an intellectual turned loose in the fields of war, not a social studies teacher. He trained and ran agents, got shot at, killed people, played the great game, charmed a debutante. The Smiley we got was so retiring that he retired from view.The biggest shame was not using flash backs to fill in the blanks. So much of this story is understated, with the expectation that the audience is acquainted with Eritish school boy life, the British caste system, military life, de-colonialization, Cold War politics, Cambridge life in the 30's. Somehow those missing pieces had to be brought out. Also, the long and bleak intro just did not make any sense. The frequent cutaways to the trainyard with voice over was completely pointless. Yes, there were trains in 60's London, just as there are today. So what.I can understand the author's keenness to be involved in the project in order to acquaint a new audience with one of his masterworks. I am sure, deep in his secret heart, Alec Guinness prowls the streets of London with a copy of Grimmelshausen tucked under his arm, his umbrella at the ready as he ruminates on the perils of a Secret Service which couldn't keep it's secrets. Please rent or watch the BBC series to really get a sense of the true depth of this masterwork.

Review title: Beautiful film but impossible to follow the story unless you've read the book
Review_body: Extremely beautiful film. However, for us who have not read John Le Carré's book, the film is quite incomprehensible. The director has completely missed out that a story has to be told, in order to give cinema visitors more than just beautiful photo and splendid acting. I left the theater like a major wandering question mark, determined to read the book to eventually give the film a second chance.Seriously speaking, the film was painfully boring and nothing much happens. Every now and then it felt pointless. I did find myself looking at my watch, wondering "When does it end?". The actors, nothing wrong, but wasting their talent on this film was really a waste of money and time. And speaking of time - remember that if you see the movie, you'll never get that time back. I already miss the two hours I spent on this overrated production.

Over the years it is fair to say that whenever someone comes out with the words "spy" and "thriller" we instantly picture Sean Connery rescuing the damsel in distress and driving an Aston Martin into a bad guy. Tinker Tailor Soldier Spy is completely different! This movie does a superb job of keeping an audience gripped in a slow moving and very intelligent and well thought out story of double agents, conspiracy and the world of British Espionage. Based on the best selling novel by John Le'Carre who was indeed a former spy in the British Intelligence this movie brings home the realism of the work of the British Secret Service through the cold war period and I'm sure things remain similar today. Gary Oldman brings to life the character of George Smiley. Smiley is a veteran spy who is called out of semi-retirement by Control (John Hurt) to track down a mole who has managed to infiltrate "The Circus" and has remained there for years and is feeding secrets to the Russians and the other communists. Oldman simply shines as the calm veteran who has seen it all and just gets on with the job at hand in a calm and professional manor. The superbly crafted cast also feature Benedict Cumberpatch, John Hurt, Colin Firth, Mark Strong and Tom Hardy do a fantastic job of bringing home the drama and throughout the movie the audience will be gripped as Gary Oldman uncovers all of the information and we get to know each of the characters in turn and in detail allowing us to feel the tension of the story. As the film unfolds and plot grows ever deeper the audience will remain on the edge of their seats and want to see the outcome of every investigation into the members of "The Circus" and remain that way right up until the credits role following an epic conclusion which I will not divulge to those of you who are yet to see this movie. In conclusion I loved every minute of this film and I urge anyone who has not yet seen it to do so. trust me this is the new benchmark for spy thrillers everywhere and you will not be disappointed. Move over 007 and make way for Smiley!!!

in the top 5 worst movies of all time. In fact, I went out of my way and spent 30 minutes creating an account (when I could be sleeping), just to write the most honest review possible. You will have more fun staring at a freshly painted gray wall, not because the fumes may alter your senses, but because staring into a blank slate until your eyes burn will yield more creativity than what this film has to offer. Not only were the quick shots of the film confusing, some of them had no place in the movie and did not add or take away from the film. Had this footage been properly ordered and edited, 30-45 minutes might have been taken out of the film or at least used to develop the characters and story. I understand that true espionage today is most likely absent of the car chases and action most movies portray, and I understand this movie was supposed to depict a realistic picture of what the Cold War was like. What I have a problem with is I am certain that there was more drama to the period of time than what this movie portrays. All I was left asking was....this is the best you can do? For all the acting, time, money, editing, writing, re-editing, printing, etc.....if this is the best "drama" that the producers could muster then they need to go back to school. Again...staring at a wall may be a better use of time than this film. Essentially, the movie shows how important paper filing and libraries are. Evidently if your log books are not kept in order then a war may start....then again no war did start so it must not have been that important after all. In short, do not watch the film unless you want to see how boring the Cold War could be. Anyone who says this movie was amazing had to be paid off or sniffing paint before they got to the movie. Literally, if you take mud and smear a white wall with it, some "artist" will walk along and say, "Oh my, the artist really is trying to contrast the darkness of life with the realness of nature" or something fake/corny like that which they think is deep and meaningful...when they just missed three children playing with the blank space next to the restroom.

the movie has lots of hidden connections between many scene's and hidden meaning to them too..like smiley looking at the the painting(which reminds him of Ann's who left him) ,the train running,bill wearing his shoe's etc..this show me how capable the director is with his art and how he can make us understand his language in his own way..this is some thing extraordinary for me the control what the director show's this is what make this movie so involving and interesting..he compresses such a big novel into a film of 2 hr 10 min..Gary oldmen show off his brilliant acting skills and brings his complete experience to play..he shows us his potential as an actor..the rest of the cast support him very well..for me this movie is one of the best of 2011..its keep you guessing till the end..must watch

Review title: Should I See This Film? It Depends On Your Taste
Review_body: You cannot go into this film expecting an action packed thriller, like Mission Impossible. Nor can you expect an action packed mystery like Sherlock Holmes. It is a slow paced mystery, that is probably more appropriately classified as a drama.If you like good acting, this film is packed with it. Gary Oldman's performance in this film is unforgettable. I could write and write about his, and all of the other actors performances, but this would turn into a very long review. To keep this short I will just say, the acting from every performer is brilliant and well worth viewing.I found the story to be phenomenal, and I have never read the book or seen any previous versions. Many however, complain that it is too confusing, and to tiresome to watch and pay complete attention too. I felt the story and pacing was refreshing. To often I find today's pictures to be too repetitive and obvious. The way this story was told was wonderful and real. It interpreted perfectly aspects of Cold War conflict. But, if you bore easy, this film will be terribly long and pointless. A good judgment of whether or not you will be bored by this film is if you are still reading this review. :)If you love the art of film making, cinematography, lighting, costuming, acting, storytelling, etc, you will love this film. If you go to the cinema to be wowed by CGI, to solve a mystery that you can solve while watching, or to get your lover in the mood, this is not the film for you. Lastly I would like to say, this film is not dark. (I'm not saying it is appropriate for young audiences, not just because of the rating but because of how bored they would be.) If you upset easily over very graphic, vulgar filled, over sexual films, this one will not upset you. It is pretty tame in those regards. I would still suggest reading the parental guide IMDb offers. Keep in mind the descriptions are very detailed on that guide though, and often make it seem worse then it actually is.I hope you found this helpful. If you did please press the "yes" button at the bottom of this review. And thank you for reading.

Wow. This movie is bad. I mean you might thing Contact with Jodie Foster was bad, but that's just peanuts compared to this movie. I would rather see a photo mosaic of the proverbial paint drying than see another frame of this poorly-written and utterly boring movie. The acting was curiously good; I particularly least-disliked Gary Oldman as George Smiley and wonder what a script-writer could have achieved had one been employed. If you find yourself in the situation of watching this movie or spooning your eyeballs out with a blunt teaspoon; the latter is the most attractive option. Once, at band camp, I realised that sadomasochistic abuse was to my taste. I used to get excited when watching anything involving Chef Ramsay. But then I realised that I wasn't depraved enough. This movie stinks. Bad. Poo-poo. Awful. Not Good. Pros: Anyone that like brown suits will like this movie. Cons: Everything else.

I have been eagerly awaiting this production for a long time and have not been disappointed. Never have I seen such a compilation of such fabulous performances together. No way is this another James Bond, it is how the world of espionage was, and is today. No car chases in Aston Martins or gadgets but a world of seedy little offices and the grim reality of this genre. What had the greatest impact on myself was the slow deep menace conveyed by all. Difficult to single out any one performance as all were amazing but I particularly admired Gary Oldman, Mark Strong and Tom Hardy for their work. At times this film has some unexpected moments of shocking cruelty. Complex character portrayal is presented in a slow deep style that only inspires you to know more about the person. The story itself is a classic and known by many, yet this production introduces a few changes which work well. One of the most absorbing and classy movies I have seen and has left a lasting impact on me. Please, please, please, make Smiley's People now.

Finally caught this wonderful film on DVD. Being a fan of le Carré's work I wasn't keen on watching it on the big screen. But I should have! Asides from the spectacular performances, the indelible score and the deftly nuanced direction, the adaptation itself handles most of the novel's complexities quite effectively. It's surprising, affecting and even touching. Yes, the Alec Guinness TV version is fondly remembered by most. However, I felt that this new version is more effective in how it challenges the viewer so that the reward at the end is exponentially more satisfying. Indeed, this is the type of film that begs to be screened more than once and I can't wait to see it again.

I've just watched the film of Tinker, Tailor, Soldier, Spy and having watched the wonderful 1979 TV series and read the wonderful book, I can honestly say that watching said film reminded me very much of the South Park episode where having watched Indiana Jones and the Crystal Skull they are forced to watch Indie being repeatedly raped using famous harrowing film rape scenes.I don't want to put everyone off seeing the film if they haven't previously seen the TV series or read the book, but I would say not to bother if you have because you will only be in for a severe disappointment.It's been a while since I spent £3 in a worse way. Benedict Cumberbatch was embarrassing and Colin Firth could not hold a candle to Ian Richardson's farts as Bill Haydon; gone is the charm and is replaced by a horrid public school bully. You learn so little about any of the mole suspects that you really couldn't care less which one of them it is. Although, surprisingly, Mark Strong, usually seen in poor quality programmes for ITV is not bad as Prideaux.More importantly, Le Carre without trade craft is not really Le Carre and I found the spies' Christmas do particularly ludicrous in this respect; according to previous versions Control is so-called because his cover is so deep no one (apart from Smiley, Maybe) knows his name. Very disappointed!
The director does not develop characters nor conflicts. The way he tells this story is incredibly boring and at the same time confusing. The enervating score does not help.

The only people that will applaud this movie is: movie critics of the all too common variety that thinks that the more boring, meaningless and artyfarty a movie is, the better it is, and fans of the book and/or original screening. Anyone else that does, should seek professional help. Because this is a movie that goes on and on without anything interesting or exiting ever happening. To call this a thriller, is like calling watching a tortoise move having a front row seat to a fast-paced race to the death. Only in the last scene something exiting nearly happens, but the director elects not to show it to us. He must have thought that after over two hours of interminable boredom, the shock of something actually happening would be too much for some and might cause heart attacks. Sometimes the editors make halfhearted attempts to liven things up - by resorting to completely unannounced and utterly confusing jumps in time and space. Gary Oldmans excellent acting skills goes completely to waste, and could easily be replaced by Sylvester Stallone and his infamous lack of emotions. This movie is SO bad, that I initially believed it to be made by Norwegian State TV (NRK).

Review title: Could have been so good if only!!!!
Review_body: Basically this is a "Who Dunnit". George Smiley is persuaded to come out of retirement, from the British Secret Service, to flush out a mole, who has infiltrated the service, to a very senior level. It has been over 20 years since I read the series of books with George Smiley in it. I do however remember that there were a whole series of clues as to who was the baddie. No such luck here. How on earth could anyone possibly have worked out who the mole was, except by guessing. There was virtually no background at all on any of the characters. There was no suspense, no excitement no anything. No I nearly forgot, there was a moment when Benedict Cumberpatch is required to illicitly steal some information for Gary Oldman (George Smiley), but that was pretty much it.

This is not an easy film to follow and I must say that I was, thanks to premium channel reruns, obliged to watch it five times. But, with each viewing, I saw wonderful acting that proffered subtle contributions to a plot that presented greater and greater insight into the brutal,vicious and mysterious world of "cold war" spying. If you stayed with "The Spy Who Came in From the Cold" and ended up enjoying it, you'll like this film even more. Nearly every site is entrancing and nearly every scene is compelling. I'm 72 years of age and that may be the influencing factor, but tears of joy sprang into my eyes when, at the end of the film, George Smiley triumphed. As a number of other reviewers have noted, it was the best end to a movie I have ever seen.

If there is one thing is this film excels in it is the eye for detail for every prop you see, all is early 70-s horror. Whole streets are reconstructed, all the cars are period correct even if they pass in the background. The trolleys files are transported in are deliciously ugly. The spectacles on peoples noses are gigantic and hideous. Whole office floors are transformed into early 1970-s misery, even the sepia colors the film was created in accentuate the fact that the flower power is dead, drab is back. And than around the 20th minute in the film there is this huge box on the desk full of files in the middle of the frame. It says Dual 505-1 on the cover. Which is a turntable that was produced by the German Dual company in 1981 and 1982. A miracle, no science, back from the future. Time travel is possible!

Review title: Absorbing and more true to life than many would like
Review_body: This is a film for watching closely. It's not one where you can miss a couple of minutes putting the kettle on, and it's not one for those times when you just want entertaining without having to think. I sympathise with people who got lost in it all, I too had plenty of issues with it after the first time of watching before realising I hadn't done the film or myself justice, so I watched it again. I then discovered it to be a very clever piece of work, and if you take the time to watch it closely and not let your concentration wander, it becomes thoroughly absorbing and all the pieces fit together wonderfully well.The cast is impressive and the performances given are memorable. This is a spy film that one could believe. I am no Bond fan, I like my entertainment to be credible, true to life, slow for much of the time, and with little false glitter.If you give the film the credit it deserves by clearing your head of extraneous matters and giving it your undivided attention, you will be handsomely rewarded.

This turns out to be one of my top ten favorites. When I first watched this film, I was not familiar with LeCarre's work, but now I feel I've discovered something great with his other works. This is one of those titles you will have to watch several times to get everything, as I did.. enjoying it more every time. I know this isn't much of a review, but I'm afraid of giving anything away. If you like movies that have a thick plot, this will be one of your favorites, even if you're not into spy movies. It's one of those films you will want to own as opposed to renting it.

I've been an IMDb "Viewer" for years but had to create my account just to post this review of this movie. It is simply the WORST. If you need to understand further, watch the Alec Guiness BBC miniseries of the same name from the 1980's, and you will know what I mean.It is really a shame that a great book, and a great made-for-TV-miniseries adaptation, has to be sullied with a remake as bad as this.The only think I liked abut this film was the sets and suits.

Review title: Not at all gripping or thrilling
Review_body: If you haven't read the book, don't bother watching. I haven't, and based on my experience and the reviews here, I think it's clear one cannot follow this movie if they haven't read the book first. Spent 98% of this movie having no flipping idea what was happening. Nearly impossible to tell when you were in a flashback or back to current. So many characters, often zero context as to who they are until too late, and rapid flipping through what each was up to. Couldn't keep track of anything. And yet the pace was somehow still a crawl. The only "gripping" thrill was in the first few minutes of the movie. In the end, you discover who the mole was, so those 10 minutes were satisfying. Maybe I'll have to try the book and then watch this again so I have some idea what's happening.

Review title: Every time I watch it I see something new.
Review_body: I love this movie. I have found that everyone in my household also loves this film. This includes people from the baby boomer generation, Gen X, and a teenager. The hazy, monochromatic tone and slow pace gradually draws you into another time and every time I watch it I discover new details, hints and clues that were previously missed. Yes, it is a little confusing the first time you watch it, but ride it out. Watch it again. I guarantee you'll grow an appreciation for it.

Review title: "How do I bore you? --Let me count the ways."
Review_body: I warmly recommend this movie to those for whom the distillation of ennui is an acquired tasted and a cherished pastime as it gives a whole new meaning to the word "Boredom".As for me, it left me baffled, very frustrated and, worse, ill at ease. I've seen late afternoon professional training programs more exciting than that! I caught myself looking at my watch, which I usually never do at the movies. In the end I no longer cared.I am quite familiar with the type of narrative technique. Tidbits of information are interspersed with flashbacks and silences, lots of long silences meant to be weighted with meaning or import it seems; the components of the puzzle at long last congealing together like a mosaic whose full effect is programmed to appear in the last 15 or 10 minutes of the movie. Nothing new. But here, this technique is so obsessively systematic as to become ponderous, tiresome, then boring and finally utterly demobilizing. The bits and pieces felt unrelated or poorly connected, but knowing that the solution would be revealed in the end, I just waited for it. For two hours I waited and waited, and waited it out. Meanwhile there was nothing engaging, involving, motivating, moving, touching, much less memorable or thrilling to alleviate the monotony of the unfolding process. It was no longer entertainment nor fiction but a process, a spy movie being deconstructed on the screen. Not the slightest emotional connection with the characters was possible. Neither likable nor hateful, they were just plain, gray, drab civil servants going to the office, a collection of perfect strangers' snapshots. The characters' personalities remained so shrunken, so sketchy, so abstract, so devoid of humanity, so disconnected from any appearance of life, so completely lacking any existence outside their place of work that I could never get to care about what was happening to them in the present nor in the end. After leaving the movie theater, someone told me that they were under the impression that Smiley was married, yet throughout the movie I took it that he was single. Anyway, how such a cold fish as he could have ever known what love is? Or would marriage have been a professional move, part of his cover? This man's only life was to go to the office, sit at a desk, shuffle papers, ask bland questions, have a drink after hours in a depressing looking house: gee, how exciting for the viewer! Empathy for the eventually victimized characters was impossible since they always remained complete strangers to one. The very violent demises left one rather detached: they came across as staged, badly staged sometimes: merely happening through actors enacting them for a movie. I felt I was watching a construct, an artificial creation, a castle of leaden Lego blocks haphazardly being put together. Never a minute was it possible to suspend disbelief; trying to understand turned into a penance. Watching Tinker, Tailor, etc, felt like atonement for having had too much pleasure with other movies such as The Descendants.This huge endeavor of a movie comes undone like a bad crosswords puzzle; it collapses under the crushing weight of its narrative technique and mystifying deliberate blandness. The conclusion merely feels like the last dot at the end of a book, leaving one uninvolved. It reminds one of the fabled mountain giving birth to a mouse (I'll skip the facile pun). This lack of drama and emotion might have been the director's point for all I do not know. So that's all it was about: bland people leading bland existences doing abstruse tedious activities at the taxpayer's expenses in a world where it endlessly rains? Nothing else but a lengthy dissertation on boring existences? Probably the traitor betrayed because he couldn't stand the tedium any longer and was dying for some excitement.Of course there's a moral, and more than one philosophical points; insightful scholarly articles with lots of footnotes will probably be written about them. If there was fodder aplenty to give academics a field day, there was not much of a story and even less entertainment.Paradoxically, the acting was very good. Poor poor actors! It was only too obvious they were giving their all trying to extricate and prop up some figments of personality from the morass in which they were obsessively confined! One felt sorry for their talent to have to fight against such unrewarding material and direction. A great pity for the actors, between two yawns, was the only emotion this movie elicited.This story felt like a very old, very worn tale exhumed out of the wet ashes of a sordid and irrelevant past in which it ought to have been left buried and forgotten. Too much Tinkering made an excellent cure for insomnia.

Review title: This is like one of those rainy, grey autumn days when nothing happens
Review_body:
... and it is really boring. And you have a flu and a headache. Have no energy and cannot think straight. If looking for this kind movie style, then this is your film. It was so boring, characters I could not care less where they end up. There is no action, no real emotion and absolutely no fun.
I give the stars for good actors and keeping the style consistent.
Everyone acts miserable by speaking in hushed tones and smoking as much as possible. The opening credits are the most depressing 5 minutes of a movie I have ever seen.

Well acted. Unfortunately the plot doesn't really build enough during the first hour to keep you occupied. The first 60 minutes could have been 15 with no loss of content or atmosphere.
After that , its a good spy drama.

Review title: Could you have put more men in one movie?
Review_body: During the first hour, the producers actually managed to give four whole women non-speaking roles - Two blonde, giggling secretaries, one woman who had their head smashed against a window, and one brunette whose naked behind we saw in a sex-scene. Very disappointing.

Review title: Probably one of the best closing sequences in a movie ever
Review_body: Really deep movie, quite difficult to keep up with, you might find yourself watching it more than 1 time just to get all the info in. Incredible acting by the whole of the cast. To top it up, as the title says, it has one of the best closing sequence ever made in a movie. Just perfect.

Review title: REALLY BAD (WOULD ADVISE NOT TO BUY)
Review_body: This movie was horrible apart from the fact that is didn't seam to have a plot or is always hard to figure out what is happening at what point in comparison to other scenes because it jumps back and forth and left and right without warning it would be better if it told you when something happened as the scenes started (ex: two years earlier, one week later, etc.) also I was sure the whole movie that two characters had the same name (not 100% sure but pretty close). I still don't get who the teacher was or the student and how they furthered the plot at all. Also in addition to this the characters didn't have very easy names either which made it harder to remember names. It also seamed to be really slow the first 30 minutes (maybe a little longer but definitely not shorter amount of time) just explains very slowly there is a mole which we could have figured out from the title. Overall I really didn't like the movie I advise against spending any money to see it and at this point in time the movie is on Netflix if you feel so inclined to waste your time.

Review title: If you haven't read the book, don't go
Review_body: I hadn't read the book, nor had I seen the TV series. I was totally clueless as to what was going on throughout the movie. Obviously it was announced that they were looking for a mole within the organization but that was the extent of any clarity about the plot. I loved the sepia tones of the film and the tone of the set decoration, etc., but the plot had way too many characters and no hints as to what was connected to what. There's a device for carrying records within the Circus that is shown over and over that looks like an oven/elevator and I never understood the reason it got so much screen time. There's one scene in which we are with Smiley as he catches a quick glimpse of a woman I assumed was his wife, but we'd never been exposed to her except by name and I couldn't see enough in the glimpse to understand what I was supposed to get from the shot. Many times there were flashback scenes that were probably meant to add to clarity about the plot but the editing was badly done and I often didn't realize it was a flashback until a few minutes into the scene. I stayed for a little more than 90 minutes of complete confusion and then my friend and I walked out. She had read the book and still didn't know what was going on - it was her idea to leave. I've only walked out of one other movie in my life and that was about 20 years ago.
Why didn't Smiley dump his wife. It appears she is at home in the last scene. What's that all about?
